{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3432418,"name":null,"username":"Mercanariesjr","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/3e96dc/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-10-08T15:33:26.643Z","cooked":"

My team is looking to upgrade from neo 1.1 with l1 on our swerve but I am unsure if we should get krakens or vortexes. if we get krakens we would probably go l3 and if we got vortexes we would probably go l2.

We found that the neo 1.1 didn’t have the speed or torque for the drive motor on swerve as most robots were faster than us and we couldn’t push anyone.

I only want to upgrade our drive motors as I don’t think we need to change the steering motor but I don’t know how easy it will be to use krakens with neos and I haven’t heard good things about vortexes.

The krakens sound great but I don’t know how easy it will be to integrate them into the robot since we have REV stuff for everything else. I have also heard you need a canivore and have one can network for rev and one for Ctre stuff but I don’t know if this is true any feed back on this would be great.

I’m not an expert but I’m curious… what gyro are you running?

Mercanariesjr:

I have also heard you need a canivore and have one can network for rev and one for Ctre stuff but I don’t know if this is true

This is an option but not necessary, especially if you just have the drive motors be Kraken.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":30,"updated_at":"2024-10-08T15:46:42.265Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":708,"readers_count":707,"score":176.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":472600,"topic_slug":"kraken-vs-vortex-for-swerve","display_username":"Amicus1","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":33946,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6995A/Choreo/Monologue"},"post_url":"/t/kraken-vs-vortex-for-swerve/472600/3","custom_user_title":"6995A/Choreo/Monologue","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3432428,"name":"Evan Kruger","username":"flightpath24","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/flightpath24/{size}/168117_2.png","created_at":"2024-10-08T15:57:45.451Z","cooked":"

In my team’s experience, Krakens are far more robust and simple to wire than Vortexes. Unless you are running Rev Maxswerve, I can’t recommend the latter. My team ran Kraken drive Neo steer this year on L2+ Mk4i (roughly the same as L3 Mk4i), which worked great.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":30,"updated_at":"2024-10-08T15:57:45.451Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":694,"readers_count":693,"score":278.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":472600,"topic_slug":"kraken-vs-vortex-for-swerve","display_username":"Evan Kruger","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":8}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51945,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"8738A | xRC | MoSim"},"post_url":"/t/kraken-vs-vortex-for-swerve/472600/4","custom_user_title":"8738A | xRC | MoSim","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":6},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":8,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3432434,"name":"Chris Bale","username":"cbale2000","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cbale2000/{size}/2142_2.png","created_at":"2024-10-08T16:02:34.190Z","cooked":"

If you’re using a Pigeon 2.0 gyro and CANcoders, Krakens integrate nicely into the CTRE swerve ecosystem and can simplify a lot of programming.
Running a separate CANivore network is technically optional, but the higher-speed CANFD bus does also come with some performance benefits, not to mention drastically reducing your overall CAN utilization.

We’ve run Krakens and before that Falcon500s, for the last few years and have been happy with both the motor performance and the ease of use for the code and wiring.

We are using the nav x 2

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":30,"updated_at":"2024-10-08T16:05:27.730Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":640,"readers_count":639,"score":138.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":472600,"topic_slug":"kraken-vs-vortex-for-swerve","display_username":null,"primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":55310,"username":"trixydevs","name":"Liam","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/trixydevs/{size}/179397_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":68351,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/kraken-vs-vortex-for-swerve/472600/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3432458,"name":"Brendan Simons, 5406","username":"nuclearnerd","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuclearnerd/{size}/7324_2.png","created_at":"2024-10-08T17:18:33.434Z","cooked":"

We used Vortexes on our Mk4i swerve modules this year, and were very happy with them.

Whichever motor you choose I recommend adding an 8mm ID x 19mm OD bearing to support the top of the motor shaft, as the Mk4i top plates flex a lot .

image500×889 45.7 KB

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":30,"updated_at":"2024-10-08T17:18:33.434Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":10,"reads":595,"readers_count":594,"score":179.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":472600,"topic_slug":"kraken-vs-vortex-for-swerve","display_username":"Brendan Simons, 5406","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.andymark.com/products/8-mm-id-19-mm-od-shielded-flanged-bearing-f698zz?sku=am-0931","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"8 mm ID 19 mm OD Shielded Flanged Bearing (F698ZZ) - AndyMark, Inc","clicks":32},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/what-do-you-think-about-the-neo-vortex-spark-flex-on-mk4/475944/9","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"What do you think about the Neo Vortex Spark Flex on MK4?","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22221,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/kraken-vs-vortex-for-swerve/472600/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3432460,"name":"jedgar6","username":"jedgar6","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jedgar6/{size}/200602_2.png","created_at":"2024-10-08T17:26:01.082Z","cooked":"

I’d note that if you go with the 16t pinion kit (L1+,L2+, or L3+) the motor shaft isn’t concentric and these bearings can not be used.

are you putting any load onto your plates beyond just the motors being supported from them? we have multiple mk4i modules we’ve been using for the last 2 years with krakens, neos, falcons, and even the 16t configuration but haven’t experienced any flexing at all

No external loads, just what plates will see due to regular motor reaction forces, and chassis bouncing. But I invite you to press down on your module top plates with your hand to see how much they move under light loads.

If you’re going to use Vortex’s with mk4i’s, absolutely add the bearings. Cracked motor faceplates are not a fun thing to discover after a match.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":30,"updated_at":"2024-10-08T20:27:53.089Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":470,"readers_count":469,"score":134.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":472600,"topic_slug":"kraken-vs-vortex-for-swerve","display_username":"Matt Middleton","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":40501,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Chief Cat Herder / Bottle Washer"},"post_url":"/t/kraken-vs-vortex-for-swerve/472600/12","custom_user_title":"Chief Cat Herder / Bottle Washer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3432549,"name":"Brendan Simons, 5406","username":"nuclearnerd","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuclearnerd/{size}/7324_2.png","created_at":"2024-10-08T21:54:04.477Z","cooked":"
mercified:

they don’t move lol

My guy, c’mon! I just took this video with only a small amount of force. It doesn’t take much deflection to increase loads on bearings.

mercified:

. do you actually think the the modules experience load like that in any matches

I dunno, but here are some quick data points:

  • A vertical bounce with an acceleration of 10g would place a 12lb load at each motor (10 x 1.2lb Kraken or Vortex/Spark weight). Is 10g reasonable? Should it be more or less?
  • The Kraken spec gives a stall troque of 9.4 Nm (83 inlbf). Acting on a 14 tooth pinion (PCD = 14/20 = 0.7in) gives a radial load of 83 in*lbf / 0.7 in ~= 118 lbf.

Both of these loads have to be restrained by the top plate. You’d have to do some FEA or testing to see how big the resulting deflections are, but my (unproven) theory is that even a little bit of deflection will cause increased loads on the motor bearing, or at least make the motor pinion mesh poorly. If so, adding a bearing on top would take away any flex between the first stage gears.

Are you certain that the issue is motors and not robot weight or tread material? What is the current draw on your NEOs when pushing? Are you current limiting?

NEOs on an L1 swerve on a 120LB robot should be able to push anything, it’ll just be slow. Upgrading motors will get you more acceleration, but pushing power is usually limited by other factors.

The poofs did that because falcons had issues where the shaft would become wobbly and render them useless (on V3 falcons, V2’s the shafts were replaceable but it was still a hassle) so supporting the shaft allowed for the motors to not see as much wear and hopefully make them last longer. Reading a little lower on that same thread, they go on to say that they likely wouldn’t support the krakens because their shafts are more robust. That slight flex in the plate is there but I don’t think it requires a bearing or any supporting because the loads on that part of the plate won’t change just because of a bearing.
